powderyMildew.name: Powdery Mildew
powderyMildew.description: A fungal disease affecting a wide range of plants, characterized by white, powdery spots on leaves and stems.
powderyMildew.lifecycle: Spores are spread by wind and germinate on plant surfaces in high humidity and moderate temperatures. The fungus overwinters in plant debris.
powderyMildew.prevention: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and apply fungicides or neem oil at the first sign of infection. Remove and destroy infected plant parts.

aphids.name: Aphids
aphids.description: Small, sap-sucking insects that cluster on new growth, causing stunted or distorted leaves and producing a sticky substance called honeydew.
aphids.lifecycle: Adults give birth to live nymphs, allowing for rapid population growth. They can be winged or wingless, spreading quickly between plants.
aphids.prevention: Encourage natural predators like ladybugs. Use strong water sprays to dislodge them or apply insecticidal soap. Keep plants healthy to resist infestation.

nitrogenDeficiency.name: Nitrogen Deficiency
nitrogenDeficiency.description: A common nutrient deficiency where the entire plant appears pale green, with older, lower leaves turning yellow and dying off.
nitrogenDeficiency.lifecycle: This is a condition, not a disease. It progresses from lower to upper leaves as the plant moves mobile nitrogen to support new growth.
nitrogenDeficiency.prevention: Apply nitrogen-rich fertilizers like blood meal, fish emulsion, or a balanced N-P-K fertilizer. Incorporate compost or well-rotted manure into the soil.

fusariumWilt.name: Fusarium Wilt
fusariumWilt.description: A soil-borne fungal disease that infects plant roots and blocks the water-conducting tissues, causing wilting, yellowing (often on one side), and eventual death.
fusariumWilt.lifecycle: The fungus can survive in the soil for years. It enters through roots, especially in warm, moist soil conditions. It is spread by contaminated soil, water, and tools.
fusariumWilt.prevention: Use disease-resistant crop varieties. Practice crop rotation with non-susceptible plants. Improve soil drainage and avoid overwatering. Sanitize tools between uses.

wheat.description: A cereal grain cultivated for its seed, a staple food worldwide.
wheat.idealConditions: Cool, dry weather during growing season. Prefers well-drained loam or clay loam soils.
wheat.wateringNeeds: Requires consistent moisture, especially during the seedling and grain-filling stages. Drought-sensitive.

rice.description: A staple food for over half of the world's population, primarily grown in flooded paddies.
rice.idealConditions: Hot and humid climate. Requires heavy clay or clay loam soil that can hold water.
rice.commonPests: Stem borer, leafhopper, bacterial blight, blast.
rice.wateringNeeds: Requires large amounts of water; fields are typically flooded for a significant portion of the growing season.

maize.description: Also known as corn, a tall annual cereal grass that yields large grains, or kernels, set in rows on a cob.
maize.idealConditions: Warm, sunny weather. Requires well-drained, fertile soil, with a good supply of nutrients.
maize.commonPests: Corn earworm, aphids, stalk borer, smut.
maize.wateringNeeds: Needs consistent moisture, particularly during the pollination and kernel development stages.

rye.description: A hardy cereal grain, often grown in cooler climates or poorer soils where other cereals fail.
rye.idealConditions: Tolerant of cold and less fertile, sandy, or acidic soils. Prefers cool conditions.
rye.commonPests: Generally resistant to pests and diseases, but can be affected by ergot.
rye.wateringNeeds: More drought-tolerant than wheat, but consistent water improves yield.

potato.description: A starchy tuber from the nightshade family, a major global food crop.
potato.idealConditions: Cool weather with well-drained, loose, sandy loam soil. Full sun is preferred.
potato.commonPests: Colorado potato beetle, aphids, late blight, scab.
potato.wateringNeeds: Requires consistent moisture. Uneven watering can lead to hollow or cracked tubers.

onion.description: A vegetable known for its pungent bulb, used in cooking worldwide.
onion.idealConditions: Full sun and fertile, well-drained soil. Early growth prefers cool weather, bulb formation needs warmth.
onion.wateringNeeds: Needs consistent moisture, but reduce watering as the tops begin to yellow and fall over to allow bulbs to cure.

cabbage.description: A leafy green, red, or white biennial plant grown as an annual vegetable for its dense-leaved heads.
cabbage.idealConditions: Cool weather crop. Prefers fertile, well-drained soil with plenty of organic matter.
cabbage.wateringNeeds: Requires consistent moisture to prevent heads from splitting. Avoid waterlogging.

peas.description: A cool-season legume crop, grown for its sweet, edible seeds.
peas.idealConditions: Cool weather. Prefers well-drained soil and appreciates support for climbing varieties.
peas.wateringNeeds: Consistent moisture is important, especially during flowering and pod development.

tomatoes.description: A widely cultivated plant for its edible berries. A key ingredient in many cuisines.
tomatoes.idealConditions: Warm, sunny conditions (6-8 hours of sun). Fertile, well-drained soil rich in organic matter.
tomatoes.commonPests: Hornworms, aphids, whiteflies, blight, blossom-end rot.
tomatoes.wateringNeeds: Consistent, deep watering is crucial. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases.

lettuce.description: A leafy annual plant of the daisy family, most often grown as a leaf vegetable.
lettuce.idealConditions: Cool weather (15-18Â°C), partial to full sun. Prefers nutrient-rich, well-drained, loamy soil.
lettuce.commonPests: Aphids, slugs, snails. Susceptible to downy mildew.
lettuce.wateringNeeds: Requires consistent moisture. Water shallowly and frequently to keep the soil evenly moist.

carrots.description: A root vegetable, usually orange in color, though purple, black, red, white, and yellow cultivars exist.
carrots.idealConditions: Cool weather (16-21Â°C), full sun. Prefers loose, sandy, well-drained, stone-free soil for straight root development.
carrots.commonPests: Carrot rust fly, aphids. Susceptible to leaf blight.
carrots.wateringNeeds: Keep soil consistently moist to prevent roots from splitting. Avoid waterlogging.

peppers.description: The fruit of plants from the genus Capsicum. Can range from sweet to intensely hot.
peppers.idealConditions: Warm weather (24-30Â°C), full sun. Prefers well-drained sandy or loamy soil.
peppers.commonPests: Aphids, pepper weevils. Susceptible to bacterial spot and mosaic virus.
peppers.wateringNeeds: Water deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry slightly between waterings.

broccoli.description: An edible green plant in the cabbage family whose large flowering head, stalk, and small associated leaves are eaten as a vegetable.
broccoli.idealConditions: Cool weather (18-22Â°C), full sun. Prefers slightly acidic, well-drained soil.
broccoli.commonPests: Cabbage worms, aphids. Susceptible to clubroot and downy mildew.
broccoli.wateringNeeds: Requires regular, deep watering. About 1 to 1.5 inches per week.

spinach.description: A leafy green flowering plant native to central and western Asia.
spinach.idealConditions: Cool weather (15-20Â°C), partial shade. Prefers nitrogen-rich, well-drained loamy soil.
spinach.commonPests: Aphids, leaf miners, slugs. Susceptible to downy mildew.
spinach.wateringNeeds: Keep soil consistently moist. Avoid waterlogged conditions.
